objects.Description: Hero, a priestess of the goddess Aphrodite, fell in love with Leander, a brave youth who swam across the Hellespont, a strait that separated them, to meet her each night. One night a tempest arose, Leander’s strength failed, and he drowned. Rinehart depicted Hero waiting faithfully for a lover who will never return. In the wake of the Civil War, many grieving widows and mothers purchased copies of this sculpture and displayed them in their homes.

objects.Description: In the decades following the advent of transatlantic steam travel in the 1830s, Americans flocked to Europe in search of art and culture. For those who could afford them, marble statues were popular souvenirs that reminded their owners of European locales, affirmed their wealth and taste, and beautified their houses. To capitalize on the lucrative tourist trade and gain access to the best marble and cheap, skilled labor, dozens of American sculptors set up studios in Italy. Joseph Mozier, a successful New York merchant, embarked on a second career as a sculptor in 1845, at the age of 33. After serving a brief apprenticeship in Florence with Hiram Powers—whose statue The Greek Slave was then creating a sensation on both sides of the Atlantic—Mozier settled in Rome, where he began producing similarly sentimental and idealized female figures.     Undine, which was first exhibited in New York in 1866, is one of Mozier’s finest works, and the sculptor received a prize for it at an exhibition in Rome in 1867. Using an array of recently improved mechanical drills, files, and measuring devices, Mozier was able to achieve a high degree of illusionism in his masterly composition, and he was particularly praised for his “perfect judgment and dexterity in the arrangement of [Undine’s] drapery.” His subject—a willowy young woman—stands in a graceful contrapposto pose. With one hand at her shoulder and the other at her head, she seems to adjust a gauzy veil that clings to her face and winds in damp folds around her torso. Her gown appears equally sheer, and the contours of her hips and legs are clearly visible beneath it. The carved drapery’s repeated diagonal folds lead the eye in a spiral around the sculpture—an effect that would have been enhanced by the original pedestal, which was designed to revolve.     Veiled female figures appear occasionally in Hellenistic and Baroque sculpture, and they became popular in the 19th century owing in large part to the mysteriously draped women carved by the Italian sculptor Raffaele Monti. In Mozier’s sculpture, Undine’s wet, clinging garments—like the waves that lap at her bare feet—allude to her aquatic origins. Mozier’s sources may have included a popular novel by Friedrich de la Motte Fouqué, a ballet by Jules Perrot and Cesare Pugni, three 19th-century operas, and an earlier ideal sculpture by Chauncey Bradley Ives, all of which derive from a German folktale about the doomed love of a water sylph for a mortal man. The sculpture by Mozier refers both to the point in the narrative when Undine, abandoned by her lover, dissolves into a column of water, and the story’s tragic ending, in which Undine rises from a castle well to give her betrayer a poisonous kiss. Undine’s thinly veiled themes of violence and eroticism were typical of 19th-century ideal sculpture, and it is interesting to note that American women—many of whom expressed increasing frustration at the circumscribed nature of their lives in the years following the Civil War—were frequently the buyers of these objects.     This is one of three known examples of Undine produced by Mozier. Beside his signature, it bears a partially inscribed date reading “186.” The fact that the last digit of the date was never completed suggests that this was one of two that remained unsold in Mozier’s studio when he died suddenly, of an unknown illness, in 1870. These works were both sold at auction in New York in 1873.Lauren Lessing

objects.Description: Alex Katz has been painting Maine subjects since 1949, when he spent his first of two summers at the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture. This depiction of a canoe on a field of blue is among his most archetypal Maine works. To achieve it Katz painted numerous studies, refining his representation of light and its reflections, and resolving questions of scale. Such planning allowed for what he has described as “great control. The bottom line of the canoe might be the best-controlled long line that I had painted.” Katz also noted that he “loved painting the fake birchbark,” a reference to the simulated birchbark on the canoe that he still uses on a pond in Lincolnville, Maine.

objects.Description: Dennis Miller Bunker painted this serene view of a tiny French fishing village, now called Larmor Plage, during the summer of 1884, when he and two other American art students visited the Breton coast while studying in Paris. Bunker and his friends sought a brief escape from the heat and social distractions of the city in the quiet atmosphere of the countryside.

objects.Description: After studying in Italy, Henry Kirke Brown returned to New York and created sculptures with distinctly national themes for the American Art-Union, an organization that distributed artworks by lottery to a broad middle-class audience. The Choosing of the Arrow was the first bronze sculpture ever cast in the United States. Although Brown visited Mackinac Island in Lake Huron to study Ottawa and Ojibwe people, he depicted this nude Italian youth as a young Apollo preparing for the hunt.

objects.Description: Whistler worked extensively on the copper plate for this portrait of Josephine Durwend, a Parisian dancer known as Finette. In a later state of the print he replaced the ledge visible at the left of the image with a low table, to which he added, among other objects, a mask and a feather, items associated with dancers and the theater. The cigarette Finette holds in her right hand, which rests against her elegant silk cloak, adds an additional element of realism to this work, which provocatively portrays a woman of the lower classes in a dignified, aristocratic manner.

objects.Description: The Irish American sculptor Augustus Saint-Gaudens dazzled his contemporaries with his images of goddesses and angels, which appeared on tombs and decorative furniture as well as alongside realistic male portraits in his powerful monuments to Civil War heroes. Articulating an artistic and cultural ideology of the period, Saint-Gaudens wrote that “besides being more superior in artistic beauty,” allegorical figures provided a “greater scope to the imagination.” The ethereal, winged figure of Amor Caritas (“love, charity”) walks toward the viewer as if from a pageant. Her tender, solemn classicism is enlivened by the deep folds and furrows that define her robes, sensuous caresses made by the artist’s hand as he shaped and formed the figure.

objects.Description: The postmaster of Lancaster, Ohio, hired Hopkins (a self-taught, itinerant painter) to make this portrait of his young daughter. Hopkins painted the child surrounded by symbolic props including a pet terrier and an imported Brussels carpet that define her as both loving and affluent. The cut rose with two unopened buds in her hand may refer to deceased siblings. Before the advent of photography, portraits like this one served as statements of parents’ social ambitions and also as private reminders of children who, all too often, did not survive.

objects.Description: In 1873 a critic writing in the New York Daily Graphic said that Winslow Homer’s works were “as fresh and full of nature as a breath of hawthorne on a May morning. The theme in all is the same—a breezy bit of landscape and a young woman . . . a possible Lillie or Fannie lies in a hammock reading with patches of sunlight lying here and there on drapery and grass.” The simple charm of this work belies its meticulous composition and finely rendered details, from the way the girl’s shoes dangle gracefully off the hammock to the sunlight that cascades across her skirt and the brilliant green that provides an idyllic backdrop.

objects.Description: Made during a trip to Amsterdam in 1889, The Embroidered Curtain is among Whistler’s most intricately worked and fully realized etchings. Water fills the foreground of the image, above which rise shopfronts in the middle distance. The horizontals and verticals of the architecture compose a grid filled with minute surface details including a lace curtain, watery reflections, and picturesque vignettes of figures framed by doorways and windows. As if to signal his satisfaction with the plate, Whistler included his abstracted “butterfly monogram” in the circular window found in the upper left corner of this image.

objects.Description: In 1977 Donald Judd began to produce wall-mounted boxes with external dimensions of 50 x 100 x 50 centimeters. These “meter boxes,” as they are known, share certain attributes: simple planes of a single metal, butt joints, and the bare minimum of artifice. This box has slightly smaller dimensions than a classic meter box, but it otherwise embodies the type, which often includes, as it does here, a slanted plane of colored Plexiglas. A chief theoretician of Minimalism, Judd did not twist plastic or cast metal or do anything traditionally associated with sculpting. Instead, he created what he called “specific objects,” nonhierarchical, three-dimensional forms that occupy space with declarative immediacy.

objects.Description: In 1957 John Chamberlain began finding his art materials at the junk heap, in particular selecting automobile parts that he used, unaltered, as "readymades," or welded into new forms. These works emerged from and commented upon an ascendant consumer culture, while also exploring a new frontier for abstract painting in the years after the emergence of Abstract Expressionism. The product of numerous complex welds, Rare Meat is nonetheless slyly singular—a vertical swipe of comingled colors and interlocking volumes.

objects.Description: One from a series of drawings made for the 1907–8 Pittsburgh Survey, a sociological study of the most heavily industrialized city in the United States, Joseph Stella’s Pittsburgh, Winter offers an aerial view of the steel town in a blizzard, with rooftops and factory chimneys visible only as vague shapes in the churning of white snow and gray smoke. Recalling the blizzard that prompted his drawing, Stella wrote that the “tragic town of the steel mills seemed transformed. She had lost that oppressive atmosphere of a damned infernal city.”

objects.Description: Old Battersea Bridge, the last surviving wooden bridge crossing the Thames in London, frequently appears in Whistler’s prints. Appealing to a market for scenes of Old London, Whistler hoped Old Battersea Bridge would sell well. In addition to relying on the picturesque tradition in Western art, Whistler was also greatly influenced by the aesthetics of the Japanese woodblock prints he had been collecting since the early 1860s. In this etching, he pulled directly from the work of the Japanese artist Utagawa Hiroshige, who emphasized the decorative qualities of bridges. The graceful arc of Old Battersea Bridge, the low vantage point from which it is depicted, and the cropping of both its ends were design elements Whistler incorporated from Japanese prints.

objects.Description: The Korean-born, New York–based artist Nikki S. Lee uses photography to document here camouflaged absorption into social groups. Here, in the company of two elderly women—Lee is the first figure on the left—she assumes the role of a senior citizen awaiting a city bus. In other instances she has posed as a drag queen, a swing dancer, a hip-hop fan, and a young urban professional, among other guises, in each case situated in a group of people whose presence either aids her disguise or contributes to its unraveling.

objects.Description: George Inness embraced a style of painting that emphasized the free and expressive use of color to capture a dynamic interaction with the natural world. In particular, he became a master of autumn landscapes. Spirit of Autumn, with its balanced composition and perfect harmony of autumnal hues, does not describe a specific time or place but instead the artist’s perception of the season, heightened by memory and emotion.

objects.Description: Having learned to etch in the 1850s, Whistler made his final series of etchings in Amsterdam in 1889. The Dance House: Nocturne shows the façade of a building at night in the city’s red-light district. Rays of light radiate from a lantern in the middle of the composition and reflect off the water in the canal below. Illuminated windows surround the lantern, so that the façade becomes a surface of sumptuous and delicate contrasts. Whistler used extra fine intersecting lines of various depths and density to achieve a seductive play of tone, ranging from rich, heavily inked dark areas to creamier sources of light. The focus on the flow of light softly dissipating into the night was inspired by Whistler’s study of Rembrandt’s etchings.

objects.Description: Miller’s many paintings of American Indians were based on sketches that he made during an 1837 trip to the Rocky Mountains with the Scottish hunter William Drummond Stewart. Buffalo Hunt with Lances is almost identical to an earlier picture that the artist painted for Stewart’s castle in the Scottish Highlands. Such scenes offered Miller’s patrons (who were mostly Baltimore businessmen) a fantasy of masculine adventure pursued outside the restrictive bounds of civilization.

objects.Description: In the fall of 1945 Marcel Duchamp visited Alexander Calder in Roxbury, Connecticut, where, among heaps of precious detritus in the sculptor’s famously overflowing studio he encountered a new group of miniature, pieced-together objects fashioned from metal scrap. During the war, when industrial materials were scarce, artists who used them exhibited resourcefulness or went empty-handed. Calder found ways to keep working, making his wartime years and the period immediately following especially productive. In one instance he sacrificed an aluminum boat, transforming this sturdy utilitarian form into a multitude of bit parts—circles, crescents, fin- and leaf-life shapes—and sending them aloft on interdependent wires. Duly impressed, Duchamp arranged for Calder to have a solo show at the Galerie Louis Carré in 1946, his first in Paris since 1933. The predominant color scheme of the exhibition was black, white, and red, so it is unlikely that this colorful work, which displays all the primaries and no black, would have been included. But it nonetheless belongs to a group of Calder’s small works in which scarcity beget ingenuity and a deep, joyous lyricism.Simple geometric and organic shapes (those leaf- and fin-like forms as well as abstracted amoebas, eggs, feathers, fishtails, and the like) are key components of Calder’s “mobiles,” so named by Duchamp in 1931 during an earlier visit to the artist’s studio, that time in Paris, where the American artist maintained a studio intermittently between 1926 and 1933. “Mobile” initially described the motorized and hand-cranked sculptures Calder made in the early 1930s, but the term was extended to the nonmotorized kinetic objects for which he became best known. These are works that in 1943 Calder recommended moving with “a slow gentle impulse ... gentle is the word.” In French, the noun mobile means “motive,” and Calder liked the double entendre this formed with the adjective common to both English and his adopted French. In 1932 Jean Arp christened Calder’s nonkinetic sculptures “stabiles,” a perfect complement to Duchamp’s term, and thus paired, the words quickly joined the burgeoning lexicon of modern art.This untitled work is a standing mobile, or a mobile with a stabile base. It features the tripod structure that Calder perfected—in this instance with legs shaped into opposing curves that bring to mind the comic disarray of a joker’s hat. Festooned, the surmounting structure counterbalances a hovering yellow crescent opposite a collection of circular metal disks that branch out, roughly descending in size from the largest, closest to the base, to the smallest. This outermost circle is nothing short of audacious, the merest pinpoint of matter intent on shaping space.Calder’s mobiles are often described in terms of weightlessness. This is partly because they take up a lot of space for their actual mass. They move irregularly, in infinite variations, like swirling tree branches. Yet despite their ability to induce a vision of weightlessness, these mobiles are among the carefully weighted and counterbalanced artworks ever made. They demonstrate dynamic equilibrium set into motion, especially in the small works, by a well-aimed puff of air.Elizabeth Finch

objects.Description: Whistler began making his “nocturnes”—abstract nighttime riverscapes that he named after a type of musical composition—in the early 1870s. This nocturne, a Venice subject, demonstrates Whistler’s innovative approach to printmaking. When he wiped the copper plate, he left behind ink to evoke watery shadows and an atmospheric sky. A contemporaneous critic protested that this work “can hardly be called, as it stands, an etching; the bones as it were of the picture have been etched, which bones consist of some shipping and distant objects, and then over the whole of the plate ink has apparently been smeared. We have seen a great many representations of Venetian skies, but never saw one before consisting of brown smoke with clots of ink in diagonal lines.”

objects.Description: Like the other stone benches in Jenny Holzer’s Under a Rock series, this granite bench has been inscribed with a brief, elliptical account of an act of horrifying violence. Inspired by her memory of a Kathe Kollwitz print of a woman who had been raped and murdered, Holzer wrote:CRACK THE PELVIS SO SHE LIES RIGHT. THIS IS A MISTAKE. WHEN SHE DIES YOU CANNOT REPEAT THE ACT. THE BONES WILL NOT GROW TOGETHER AGAIN AND THE PERSONALITY WILL NOT COME BACK. SHE IS GOING TO SINK DEEP INTO THE MOSS TO GET WHITE AND LIGHTER. SHE IS UNRESPONSIVE TO BEGGING AND SELF-ABSORBED. This graphic invocation of male sexual violence suggests how pervasive, and yet how often unremarked, such brutality is in contemporary culture. It is one of the many forms of extreme cruelty and inhumanity that might “crawl out from under a rock,” were we to lift it. Holzer’s larger interest in this series is in exploring the “man-made catastrophes” that result from unresolved political conflicts, but this specific piece is a powerful example of the feminist critique of male dominance that energizes much of Holzer’s work.      Carving block letters into the seat of a stone bench that might be located in many public contexts enables Holzer to communicate with a broad general audience. The contrast between what is described and the cool, matter-of-fact language in which it is described is startling, but this language also mimics the detached tone in which newscasters regularly report appalling acts of terror and violence. Like much of the rest of Holzer’s work, which uses the languages and the forms of mass culture to draw attention to the words and images we absorb and accept unthinkingly, this bench challenges us to focus on the reality and the experience of violence against women. And in its material evocation of tombstones, war memorials, and other forms of public commemoration of the dead, the bench invites us to mourn for the countless, anonymous victims of a structurally unequal, misogynist society. Margaret McFadden

objects.Description:
Thomas Ball was a sculptor who depicted famous Americans such as George Washington and Daniel Webster. One of his best-known works is Emancipation Group, which represents Abraham Lincoln holding the Emancipation Proclamation before a kneeling black slave. In the aftermath of Lincoln’s assassination, Ball created this sculpture to honor Lincoln and his accomplishments. Eleven years later, he was commissioned to make a large public version, which was paid for by emancipated slaves. Ball had served as his own model for the kneeling figure in the first version, but for the later commission he modeled this figure after Archer Alexander, the last slave captured under the Fugitive Slave Act. Emancipation Group has become controversial over the years. Today there are two opposing views of this artwork: on the one hand that the slave is rising to claim his freedom, and on the other hand that he is crouching at the feet of a white man.

Emily Rosales ’16

objects.Description: To produce this groundbreaking publication Thomas McKenney, the head administrator of the Office of Indian Affairs, hired master printmakers to make lithographs based on portraits of American Indian leaders and their families, most of which were painted by Charles Bird King. He then appointed James Hall, a lawyer and well-known author, to write accompanying biographical texts. Published over the course of eight years, these volumes are now recognized as a pioneering anthropological study on the subject of Native Americans.

objects.Description: A master of the contemporary grotesque, Dana Schutz uses the painting medium to envision hypothetical realities, moving adeptly between overtly fictional themes (the artist, for example, has painted her self-portrait as a pachyderm) and abstractions with whispering undercurrents of narrative. Schutz created the large, pitch-black dots in this work by cutting holes in the canvas and adding a recessed backing of velvet. She intended for these “graphic interruptions,” as has described them, to be “as fictive as anything else” in the painting. Inserting an act of illusionism into an ostensibly non-referential image is characteristic of an artist who approaches her subjects, including the iconography of abstraction, with irreverence and wit.

objects.Description: At first glance, this photograph by Harry Callahan presents a formidable challenge—if not a nearly impenetrable opacity. Though apparently artless, it is precisely its lack of pretension or cant that gives this enigmatic image its enduring strength. Given more attention, the photograph’s remarkable clarity and straight-on vantage point begin to disclose the photographer’s exceptional craft and acute visual intelligence. The modestly sized print (tiny when compared with the supersized photographs we see today) displays a delightful collection of details and range of tones that ultimately demand a thoughtful, up-close examination. In a visual culture in which a constant barrage of quick-read, easily digestible imagery is the norm, that alone might be considered a noteworthy event.     But still, this finely rendered picture of a woman and small girl standing side by side on an empty cobblestone street remains a puzzle. It could be dismissed as an intriguing but otherwise ordinary family picture of little interest to the average viewer. The unusually great distance between the photographer and his subjects might even be assessed as the miscalculation of a photographer who simply didn’t know enough to move closer. But to take this image out of the context of the series to which it belongs would be akin to looking at a single Eugene Atget photograph and labeling it merely a nostalgic view of old Paris.     Eleanor and Barbara, Chicago is part of a series Callahan made of his family in a variety of Chicago landscapes, such as city parks, industrial areas, and at Lake Michigan. In many, his subjects stare directly at the camera from a greater distance than is usually expected in a portrait. In this particular photograph, the mother and child punctuate the urban landscape as doll-like figures. While the duo’s diminutiveness could imply that they are inconsequential to the photographer and his photograph, the series in total reveals their vital importance to the artist, and thus places them—figuratively at least—front and center in these pictures.     And then there’s the print itself, made by direct contact with the large film negative. This is no virtual photograph floating in the cyber-world as a conglomeration of approximated pixels. This is, after all, a print made by Callahan himself. The eight-by-ten-inch piece of gelatin-silver paper upon which the image is printed accommodates the negative neatly from edge to edge; no paper is wasted and no part of the original negative goes unrecorded. The print’s subtlety can be astonishing. In what at first seems to be a solid light gray sky, there appears a delicate whisper of white clouds toward the right side of the picture, so close in tone to the sky it disappears entirely in even some of the finest reproductions of this work.      Like many artists, Callahan helped support his work by teaching. Although evidently a reluctant pedagogue, he was a powerful artist-as-teacher role model for his students, among them Emmet Gowin, now himself an important artist and university professor. Gowin’s noteworthy series of photographs of his wife, Edith, and her extended family is surely the legacy of his mentor’s influence.     The photographs Callahan made of Eleanor alone and with Barbara not only suggest the complexity and depth of his feelings for his wife and daughter but, even more significantly, present evidence of his desire to include them in his life’s other great passion: photography. Go further with his work and you’ll continue to see his prodigious talent married to surprising humility. It’s all there, though none of it, like the photograph in this collection, gives itself up easily. Harry Callahan worked hard at his art. His art demands the same of us.Gary M. Green

objects.Description: In 1935, Samuel Rosenberg declared that, “So far as having a personal style is concerned, artists can do that when they are old.” Over the course of the 1930s, he experimented with various methods to depict the people, buildings, and landscape of Pittsburgh, the city where he would work and teach for sixty years. In Sideshow, Rosenberg combined the colorful palette and populist subject matter of Regionalism with a faceted Cubist surface. His subject is the sideshow of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, which set up its tents in Pittsburgh every July. A barker, a brass band, and exotic dancers perform, enticing the crowd to pay up and see the human oddities behind the curtain wall.

objects.Description: This beautiful bronze bell from the late Western Zhou period is a highlight of the Colville Collection of Early Chinese Art. Standing some 17 inches tall, the graceful instrument has a flattened ovoid shape with sides tapering gently inward toward the top. This bell belongs to a relatively small group known as bo, or clapperless bells that hang from a loop at the top. The few examples of Western Zhou bo excavated in controlled archeological contexts mostly come from Hunan province in southern China, the homeland of Yue people, who had commercial and cultural contact with the Zhou state to their north.(1) Solemn music played on bronze bells featured prominently in state rituals at the Western Zhou court, and this and related bells suggest that the Yue and other peoples on their southern periphery also possessed a highly sophisticated musical culture.     The bell’s surface decoration consists of several disparate and unusual motifs, motifs found primarily on a handful of southern bronzes of this period. A series of plumelike shapes erupts along the central vertical axis of each face, echoing similar shapes extending out from the two sides, where they culminate at the top of the bell with exquisite phoenixes with crowns of fanciful plumage. At the lower center of both faces is a U-shaped form reminiscent of the horns commonly associated with the taotie mask (for an example of the taotie, see the Western Zhou li); however, the other elements of the mask motif are not present, except perhaps for eyelike circular bosses which stare out at us from atop the horns. The disintegration of the taotie design and the rearrangement of its individual elements is associated with bronzes from the Yue and other southern groups far from the center of royal Zhou power. For these peoples, the conservative taotie design apparently held less spiritual power.      The most puzzling designs on this bell are the wormlike shapes arrayed horizontally in four rows on both the bell’s faces. These creatures adorn only three other known bronzes: a nao-type bell in the Art Institute of Chicago, a bo bell illustrated in a Japanese publication, and another nao bell excavated in Zhuzhou County, Hunan, in 1989.(2) Although the design has been referred to as a dragon or a lizard, its legless body distinguishes it from these creatures more commonly found in bronze decorations. In fact, the closest visual correlate in the natural world is not a reptile but an insect: the silkworm. The silkworm’s segmented body, its two tentacles, and its S-curved motion have been perfectly captured by the artist of this bell. This prompts a question: why would the Yue people decorate a ceremonial bell with silkworms?      Sericulture had already been practiced in China for thousands of years; by the Western Zhou period, textiles made from the worms’ cocoon fibers were both emblems of luxurious wealth and valuable commodities in interregional trade.(3) In fact, the Yangzi River Valley, whence the bell comes, was a major silk producing region, and its economy depended upon the harvest of silk fibers. Earlier Shang-period sources tell of rituals to venerate silkworms and silk deities, and small jade sculptures of silkworms have even been found in Western Zhou tombs. The life cycle of the silkworm—its transformation from an immobile egg to a flying insect—could also impart a symbolic function to its artistic representation on ritual objects such as this bell. Ankeney Weitz1. Gao Zhixi, “Shang and Zhou-Period Musical Instruments from South China,” Bulletin of the School of Oriental and African Studies 55:2 (1992), 271; Gao Zhixi, “Lun Shang Zhou tong bo” [A discussion of bronze bo of the Shang and Zhou] (1986), reprinted in Hunan chutu Yin Shang Xi Zhou qingtongqi [Bronze objects of the Shang and Zhou excavated in Hunan] (Changsha, Hunan: Yueli shushe, 2007), 576–82.2. For illustrations, see: Art Institute of Chicago online catalogue www.artic.edu/aic/collections/artwork/12086 (accessed August 12, 2008); Fritz Kuttner, The Archaeology of Music in Ancient China (New York: Paragon House, 1990), 43; Hunan chutu Yin Shang Xi Zhou qingtongqi, pl. 11:1.3. For a summary of the cultural significance of silk in the Shang and Western Zhou periods, see Shelagh Vainker, Chinese Silk: A Cultural History (London: British Museum Press, 2004), 20–34.

objects.Description: This low-slung tripod vessel (li) cast of bronze, now covered with patina, may seem rather unassuming at first glance. However, closer inspection reveals a crisply cast, intricate surface decoration, and a mysterious 33-character inscription tucked under the rim of the lip. Zhou nobles used bronze vessels such as this one to propitiate their ancestors and to commemorate important political events; they treasured these vessels as family heirlooms and placed ritual sets in the graves of their deceased parents. Despite the ritual importance of these vessels, bronzes of the artistic quality of this li-type tripod and bearing commemorative inscriptions are still relatively rare among excavated examples.     An interlocking design of fantastical birds with elaborate, flowing plumage circles the body of the vessel, broken only by three monsterlike faces protruding from the surface above the three legs. A similar mask stares out at us from the base of each foot. Scholars debate the function and meaning of these designs on ancient Chinese bronzes. Most agree that the rhythmic zoomorphic and geometric embellishments enhance the beauty and proclaim the importance of the vessel. However, some investigators also insist that these animal images must have symbolic meaning, serving as emblems associated with the spiritual and ritual lives of the vessels’ owners, the kings and nobles of tightly knit and very powerful clans. For instance, some experts assert that the phoenixlike birds here would symbolize the force of the wind, or alternatively serve as heralds for a clan. The monster mask, often called taotie, has been the subject of even more controversy: does its evil gaze ward off harmful spirits? Or does the gaping upper jaw of a monster that devours all in its path auger the passage from human to spirit realms? Hypotheses abound; however, no satisfactory explanation has fully accounted for the presence or the content of these mysterious decorations.     The inscription assigns its commissioning to one Xiao of the State of Cao, a small feudal kingdom bestowed by the Zhou king upon his younger brother in the mid-11th century B.C.E. This attribution to the Cao State makes the li tripod a rarity, for only a handful of known bronzes have been associated with this small state.(1) The brief text can be translated roughly as follows:The Heavenly Mother Duan aided Xiao, the son of Cao. He vanquished a foe. As a sacrifice [to the ancestors], he did not kill the man but instead cast this precious li of “black and red” metals. [If one] is neither brave nor imposing, he cannot strike fear in the enemy. Cherish and use [this vessel] forever.     Xiao, the original owner of this bronze, is most likely Xiaogongyun, the fifth ruler of Cao, who lived during the reign of King Jian of Zhou (reigned 899–892 B.C.E.). Although we know almost nothing about Xiao except his name, the tombs of the rulers of this state have recently been identified in Shandong province. Should controlled archeological excavations at this site take place in the future, we will know much more about the context for this extraordinary vessel.Ankeney Weitz1. Liu Yu illustrates six examples in his “Liang Zhou Caoguo tongqi kao” [Research on bronzes from the Kingdom of Cao of the Zhou Period], Zhongyuan wenwu (February 2008), 42–46.

objects.Description: The demands of illustration to produce a clear communicative image, early on, became the central focus of Winslow Homer’s work. Illustration graphics have been more influential in America than in Europe, although Cézanne and Manet used graphics at times for inspiration. Other Americans influenced by graphics include Edward Hopper, Georgia O’Keefe, and Andy Warhol. Homer’s work retains a strong graphic image; however, he also gives a lot of perceptual information with light and motion and virtuoso painting. Sargent, who also combined perceptual light with brushwork, did not make engaging images.     This amazing watercolor does it all. The figures’ gestures capture motion, and the gestures are original compared with most European painting, which are more traditional, particularly when dealing with movement. The light from the left which does not define the back of the boat makes the boat move to the right, and the long diagonal blue line accelerates the motion. The three oblique angles of the figures’ right side also help propel the movement. The gestures are both firm and moving.     The liveliness of the brushwork adds to the plausibility of the painting. It gives plausibility that no photo can match.Alex Katz

objects.Description: Winslow Homer was born in Boston in 1836. As a young man he became an apprentice at John H. Bufford’s and Sons, lithographers, which was the beginning of a career as an illustrator for newspapers. He moved to New York in 1859, the year after Harper’s Weekly had been founded. Homer had sent illustrations to the periodical before he moved to the city, and after he arrived there he became one of its regular illustrators until 1875. His great output there was wood engravings of the Civil War period. The weekly sent him to the front, yet with few exceptions, his illustrations did not depict battle scenes but rather life in camp. In 1866 and 1867 Homer was in Paris, where he exhibited two paintings at the Universal Exposition.[1] In the early seventies he began to paint seriously in watercolor, a medium that hitherto had been, with few exceptions, the province of amateurs. Many of them were painted at Houghton Farm, a farm near West Point that belonged to Lawson Valentine, with whom the painter’s brother Charles worked. The watercolors done there were of children pursuing rural activities such as gathering berries. In 1881–82 Homer traveled to Cullercoats, a village on the North Sea of England. His sojourn produced a dramatic change in his work, especially his oils. He captured the power and danger of the sea, which he focused on after 1883, when he moved to Prouts Neck, Maine, where he died in 1910.     Homer made many trips to the Adirondacks between 1870 and 1910, although he did little work there after 1900. The Trapper was painted on his first trip. It depicts a man, the trapper, standing on the trunk of a tree that has fallen into the water. Beyond him are islands, the pond, and the opposite shoreline. Placed at a slight angle in the canoe is a jack light which, when a candle or lantern was lighted in the receptacle on the pole at night, would be used to startle deer. A second version of The Trapper, called An Adirondack Lake, is in the collection of the Henry Art Gallery, University of Washington.  The most obvious difference, aside from its being larger (24 x 38 in.), is that the jack light is not upright in An Adirondack Lake, but rests on the edge of the canoe. They are both dated 1870; it is not known for certain which was painted first. It is known, however, that at least one occasion, in 1866, Lawson Valentine, who had become a patron of the artist, commissioned a version of a canvas that Homer had painted the previous year and that Valentine had failed to acquire.[2]     Lawson Valentine as well as other members of his family were supporters of Homer, especially during the 1870s, and acquired both oils and watercolors by him. Winslow Homer’s brother Charles worked for the Valentines and eventually became chairman of the board of Valentine & Company, a successful varnishing company in New York. Lawson Valentine himself had forty works by the artist. His daughter Almira married Nathan Trowbridge Pulsifer and was the mother of Harold Trowbridge Pulsifer, who married Susan Nichols.  A poet, Harold T. Pulsifer died in 1948, and his wife donated The Trapper to Colby College the next year. At the same time she placed on loan eleven works by Homer in the Valentine-Pulsifer Collection, which had been left in trust to her. Upon her death in 1987 the collection went to a niece, and most of it is now in the National Gallery of Art in Washington, DC.Hugh J. Gourley III1. The museum has in its collection a painting done in Paris. It is Portrait of Pauline, 1867, oil on canvas, 22 x 15 inches, gift of Miss Adeline F. Wing and Miss Caroline R. Wing, 1962.025. Pauline sold perfume and soap at the Universal Exposition.2. The Valentine-Pulsifer painting is Army Teamsters, 1866, now in the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, Richmond; it is based on The Bright Side, 1865, in the collection of the Fine Arts Museum of San Francisco.

objects.Description: This vase is representative of trends in porcelain decoration during the reign of the Kangxi emperor, the second ruler of the Qing dynasty (1644–1911). The traumatic events connected to the fall of the Ming dynasty and the rise of the Manchu Qing led to a decline in imperial patronage during the latter part of the 17th century; in response, the potters of Jingdezhen, the imperial kiln, began producing wares designed to appeal to a new clientele of literati-gentry and wealthy merchants who emulated their lifestyles. Julia B. Curtis, in a 1995 catalogue, noted three major innovations in porcelain decoration as a result: scenes resembling landscape painting, auspicious motifs relating to scholars and success in the imperial exams, and narrative scenes borrowed from woodblock print illustrations of fiction and drama. The scenes on this vase incorporate all three, with the strongest influence clearly being woodblock illustrations. The plots of traditional works of fiction and drama are often summarized in a parallel couplet that serves as either introduction or conclusion. The two scenes on this vase represent an interesting visual riff on this narrative technique. Both the top and bottom scenes can be divided into three sections, with top and bottom paralleling each other—trees growing in a garden (fig. 1); human figures in a garden (fig. 2); and, contiguous and open to the garden, an interior of a scholar’s study. In both the top and bottom sections in figure 1, a stone path leads to two gnarled trees intertwined against a background of a rock formation. However, the lower picture is framed by an arch, which leads to an incense table, and on the other side of the tree and stone formation the garden is bounded by a balustrade. In all three parallel sections the bottom setting is similar to, but more elaborate than, the one above. Perhaps they show the same garden at two different times, the top before and the bottom after the owner has experienced an upturn in fortune. The other component scenes support this conjecture.In the top garden scene an immortal descending from heaven—indicated by the cloud formations on which he stands—is raining down coins from a money string onto a servant, who is gathering up the windfall. Moving to the interior scene we see three men dressed in scholars’ clothing happily watching. The three have their backs to an incense table, behind which is hung a scroll depicting the very same immortal. The incense burner on the table suggests that they have been honoring the immortal and are being rewarded for their piety. If the top interior scene evokes one fantasy of the scholar-official class—wealth raining down from the sky, untainted by crass mercantilism—the interior scene on the bottom part of the vase indicates another. Here three men are depicted receiving formal greetings from fellow scholars and a military man in full regalia; in the contiguous garden scene another scholar hurries to join them. The three men’s clothing, the deference they receive from the others, the writing implements spread before them, and the sumptuous decorations of the room imply the power and privilege of the scholar-official class. Perhaps this vase originally graced a study very similar to the ones depicted on it; it surely served as both auspicious emblem and idealized depiction of the hopes and aesthetic values of the members of the literati-gentry.Kimberly A. Besio

objects.Description: Theorem painting—sometimes called poonah painting or oriental tinting—was a popular decorative art form in the United States throughout the middle decades of the 19th century. Its mastery was such an essential element of a girl’s education that a writer in 1838 described a typical female seminary as follows: “Crowded room; young ladies in white and blue—on the walls, theorem paintings, birds and flowers, and bead-work purses, reticules, and pin cushions—music on the piano.” Whether theorem paintings were made on wood, paper, silk, or velvet, the process was the same. The painter began by tracing a still-life design onto oiled or waxed sheets of paper. She then cut out individual shapes to create stencils—or “theorems.” By painting through these theorems onto the desired surface, she worked up a still-life painting shape by shape. Finally, the artist would add highlights and details freehand. Many 19th-century theorem paintings were based on popular prints; however, artists freely rearranged the elements within their compositions.This still life of grapes and peaches in a wicker basket is an excellent example of theorem painting, executed on exactly the type of “firm, white cotton velvet” recommended by “Madame L.B. Urbino, Prof. Henry Day, and Others,” the authors of the 1860 book Art Recreations. The flatness and linear precision of the painting’s design are clear indicators of the process used in its making; however, the artist of this particular theorem painting was both creative and highly skilled. Her modeling of individual forms is deft, and her pairings of complementary colors and rounded and angular shapes created a forceful and pleasing visual rhythm. The original frame was painted to resemble mahogany, with a radiating pattern of faux graining that draws the eye inward toward the composition. This theorem painting was undoubtedly created to serve as domestic decoration. Originally, it would have hung in a dining room over a table or sideboard, adding a bit of color. It is not hard to see, however, why American collectors in the 20th century prized such works. The painting’s flatness, abstract forms, and bright colors seem to offer a native precedent for European modernist art. In particular, the painted marble tabletop on which the basket of fruit rests is tilted up toward the picture plane and lit from the left, while the fruit basket is seen and illuminated from an incongruous angle, calling Cubist still-life compositions to mind.Lauren Lessing

objects.Description: Thomas Chambers’ landscape is one of a large number of American folk paintings given to Colby College in 1956 by the Waterville collectors Ellerton and Edith Jetté. Like many works in their collection, including a Painting of Fruit on velvet (page 00), Chambers’ painting appealed to mid-20th-century American viewers because it seemed to offer a vernacular precedent for European modernism. With its bright colors, graphic boldness, and expressive abstraction of forms, the picture almost might have been painted by the French Post-Impressionist Henri Rousseau or one of his early-20th-century admirers among the group known as the Fauves. Small wonder, then, that the Macbeth Gallery in New York labeled Chambers the “First American Modern” in 1942. The Macbeth Gallery exhibition and the press surrounding it mythologized the artist (about whom next to nothing was known) as a native, self-taught genius whose avant-garde paintings went largely unappreciated in his lifetime. A 2007 exhibition at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, curated by Kathleen A. Foster, overturned this view. Foster linked Chambers instead to his own historical moment in the mid-19th century.     Thomas Chambers was most likely the younger brother of the English marine painter George Chambers. It was probably George who in 1825 took him from their family home in Whitby, near the northeast coast of England, to London. There, the younger Chambers may have learned his trade from his brother, who was then working as a theatrical scene painter. Stylistically, Thomas’s paintings do resemble the vividly painted backdrops and panoramas popular at the time. After immigrating to the United States in 1832, however, he specialized in “fancy” pictures—small, decorative, cabinet paintings that are almost always unsigned, and that may have complemented similar compositions executed on mirrors, fireboards, and other furniture. Chambers’ contemporaries Thomas Cole and Charles Codman (page 00), began their careers working in a comparable naïve, decorative mode, but later painted highly mimetic Romantic landscapes that won them the favor of wealthy American art patrons. Chambers, on the other hand, never varied his style, and his buyers continued to be middle-class consumers seeking pleasing, affordable domestic decoration. Catering to this need, he eked out a living in various American cities including New Orleans, New York, and Boston before returning to his native Whitby, where he died, impoverished, in 1869.      This is a fine example of Chambers’ whimsical, decorative style. The artist may have based his composition on an as-yet-undiscovered print depicting Hudson River scenery, but in any event, in his hands the scene is a purely imaginary vista. From the vantage of a shady, flower-spangled lawn (reminiscent of an Axminster carpet) the viewer looks out over a broad, calm river toward rolling mountain slopes under a cloudy, blue, late summer sky. Sailboats and seagulls drift by, and the foothills above the opposite bank shelter a village whose picturesque rooftops and white church steeple are just visible. The vertical shape of the canvas is echoed by various compositional elements, including the tall, sinuous tree in the left foreground, the blue, green, and mauve mountains, and even the rosy clouds, which bend and curve around the margins of the picture, mirroring the feathery foliage of the trees. The horizon, tinted bright yellow to indicate sunrise or sunset, divides the canvas neatly in half, and the rhythm created by alternating areas of light and shadow pulls the viewer’s eyes around the composition. Ensconced in a mid-19th-century parlor and illuminated by candle or lamplight, this bold little painting would have held its own, creating an imaginary window while, at the same time, harmonizing with the brightly tinted decor. Lauren Lessing

objects.Description: The portrait of the Reverend Silas Ilsley is one of the earliest American paintings in the Colby collection, given a half-century before there was even a hint of having a college museum. A graduate of Waterville College (later Colby) in 1834, Ilsley attended Newton Theological Seminary and from 1837 to 1861 preached in Maine, New Hampshire, Connecticut, and New York. He later became district secretary of the American Baptist Publication Society. Donated by his family soon after his death in New York in 1886, the work was first hung in Memorial Hall on the original downtown campus, along with less refined portraits of notable Colby people, including the Union General Benjamin Butler, trustee and Lincoln’s vice president Hannibal Hamlin, and professor Samuel Francis Smith, author of the words to the paean America.     In the 1950s, when the Mayflower Hill campus was new, the painting hung in the Miller Library office of President J. Seelye Bixler, the man credited with establishing fine art and music at Colby. Staring down from the wall of the finest office on campus, the portrait was surely an iconic reminder of the early years of the college when so many graduates were teachers or preachers, or both. Museum founder James M. Carpenter saw it when he came to visit Bixler prior to his appointment as Art Department chair. Carpenter later recalled his eyes “kept slipping up to an arresting portrait of a young man who steadily returned my gaze.” From that day forward, Carpenter said the Ilsley portrait was among his favorite Colby-owned paintings.     Although the artist is unknown, the piece is not typical of the more “primitive” portraits done by the workaday American artists of the early to mid-19th century. It is more refined, perhaps more European. While itinerant painters often hid the hands for being too complicated, this artist dared to include them (albeit, as Carpenter noted, in a somewhat “wooden” fashion), the right hand poised with quill and paper, perhaps prepared to write a sermon. The face is sophisticated and expressive. The edges of the starched white shirt collars leap out, and the penetrating, following eyes suggest a man of unwavering Old Testament virtues.     The mystery of the artist’s identity was heightened in the early 20th century by the discovery in the Senate House Museum in Kingston, New York, of a painting that apparently is a copy of the Colby canvas, but with modifications and less skillfully executed. Carpenter speculated, based on the painting technique of using transparent glazes, that Colby’s original is by a French artist, trained in the tradition of Ingres and possibly visiting from nearby Canada. In any case, the rareness of the work is enhanced by the fact that few rural American preachers of the period could afford to have their portraits made. Precious few of them exist.     Moreover, the painting has special meaning at Colby where, between 1830 and the end of the 20th century, representatives of six successive generations of Ilsleys have attended the college.Earl H. Smith

objects.Description: As a founding member of the German Expressionist group Die Brücke in 1905, Kirchner was interested in building bridges between modern Germany and other art forms: the German past, French contemporary movements such as Fauvism and Cubism, and so-called primitive art. What the Germans meant by “primitive” at this time was more a reaction against Academic art—the kind of classically oriented styles taught in schools of fine art—than an endorsement of art from any particular society. Kirchner was interested in both Oceania and Africa, but for him “primitive” meant exotic, anti-academic, sincere art uncorrupted by the strictures of European bourgeois civilization. Kirchner found the primitive where it might be expected; say in the work of van Gogh, but also in more curious locales, such as the island of Fehmarn, off the Baltic coast of Germany, far from Oceania, Africa, or, for that matter, France.     Kirchner began visiting Fehmarn in 1912 with Erna and Gerda Schilling, sisters he had just met in Berlin. He would form a relationship with Erna that lasted until his suicide in 1938, but on Fehmarn he was fascinated by “the beautiful, architectonically constructed, severely formed bodies” of both sisters, and he made numerous nude studies of them on the beaches and in the forests of the island. These culminated in his large Striding into the Sea of 1912, a monumental evocation of the artist’s nudist forays with the Schillings.[1] Kirchner continued to summer on Fehmarn until 1914, when rumblings of war made the island off limits to civilians. In 1912 Kirchner and the sisters had rented apartments from the keeper of the Staberhuk lighthouse, on the southeast coast of the island, and the upstanding family of the beacon keeper must have been shocked by the antics of the artist and his models. Nude subjects, especially nudes in nature, dominated Kirchner’s work from this period, but he also concentrated on images of nature itself, as in Laburnum Tree.     The laburnum represented in Kirchner’s painting was in the garden of the lighthouse keeper. Typically the showy blossoms of the laburnum tree appear from May to June in Europe. This far north, June is more likely, providing an approximate date for the painting. The laburnum tree—Goldregen, or golden rain, golden chain, in German—is known for its profuse display of golden flowers arranged in loose, pendulous racemes. The flowers are poisonous in sufficient amounts, but were also indicated in medicinal doses for dyspepsia, whooping cough, and asthma. But neither toxicity nor pharmacology was on Kirchner’s mind when he painted Laburnum Tree. Kirchner thought the vegetation on Fehmarn was exotic and he viewed the Goldregen as a floral expression of the full bounty of nature on the island, the arboreal counterpart of the nudes in nature that dominated his work there.      Kirchner concentrated on the blossoms, allowing them to set the color harmony of the painting. Thus they are set off, in terms of warmth, from the cool greens and blues of leaves and shadows. Equally, the blossoms counter, in terms of color, the complementary violet of the paths surrounding the tree. The blossoms of the laburnum tree are very complex, almost orchidlike, but Kirchner eschewed detail here for aggressively abstract, Fauvist brushwork, so we read opposing strokes of paint as much as blossoms, leaves, tree trunks, or sand paths. The primitive power of the exotic landscape is rendered in terms of a fully loaded brush attacking the canvas, an expression of Kirchner’s fierce love of nature, his devotion to modern French art, and a spectacular German landscape.Michael Marlais1. Kirchner’s Striding into the Sea, 1912, is in the Staatsgalerie Stuttgart, Germany.

objects.Description: Eastman Johnson’s Lunchtime is a seemingly quintessential American painting in the way that it represents American values of honesty, simplicity, and directness. In the center of the composition two boys face each other. The older one, with puffy, food-filled cheeks, holds a spoon and a bowl and leans against a chair, while his much younger companion is on his knees and looking up at him. The simple domestic setting is appropriately represented by muted color relationships, largely based on a subdued range of hues.The two boys establish a triangular or pyramidal composition, as classical an arrangement and as firmly rooted as one could find in any Renaissance work. The composition as well as the chiaroscuro emphasize the central figures and add gravity to the everyday scene. Johnson’s highly skilled manipulation of traditional painterly and design elements combined with the seemingly simple approach to painting, at first glance seeming to reflect the purity and directness of American values, is in fact highly contrived.However charming the painting seems initially, there is more than anecdote being presented here. At the bottom right of the painting corncobs are arranged to form an architectural structure that in combination with a single cob on an empty spool, making the form of a cannon, create a toy fort. At the lower left, flower petals are scattered on the floor, as if they had casually blown in through the open doorway. Although the primary composition is formed by the two figures, the chair placed between them fills the central space, uniting the major compositional group. At the same time, the vertical spindles of the chair’s back function as a fence that divides the figures. This play on unity and separation is key to a fuller reading of the painting.The canvas is dated at the bottom right to 1865, the year that marked the end of the long Civil War. I believe this painting is an allegory of that event or, perhaps better stated, of its consequences. The children’s corncob-and-spool toys are instruments of war, albeit humble ones, while the flower petals on the other side of the composition suggest peace, a fitting and meaningful juxtaposition. Further, the chair functions here as a memorial for the losses incurred during the war, for those who are missing. In the Civil War era unoccupied chairs often served as gravemarkers, and a popular Civil War song written by George Frederick Root in 1861 was entitled “The Vacant Chair,” referring to a soldier who would never return to his family.There is compelling evidence of Johnson’s interest in the Civil War and in representing it: he was present at the front at Bull Run, Antietam, and Gettysburg, and a number of his paintings represent specifically Civil War themes. Recognizing the iconographic meaning of Lunchtime, its anecdotal details become more notable. There is, in fact, no evidence to suggest that the title was Johnson’s own. However, a work by Johnson auctioned at the very end of 1865 titled Not Enough for Two would be a likely match for the Colby painting. At the end of the war, there was general concern about food and sustenance in America.The metaphor of brothers divided with insufficient resources to sustain them both would have been a poignant one for a country torn apart by a fratricidal civil war and would have resonated with other divisions that were of preeminent concern to Americans of the time. After all, America’s losses were multiple, its divisions manifold. If Johnson’s painting is quintessentially American, it is so not only because of the simplicity of its subject and the seeming directness with which it is portrayed, but also because it makes manifest the complicated, indeed contradictory, nature of America just at the end of the Civil War.David L. Simon

objects.Description: I sit and gaze on this highest peak of all;Wherever I look there is distance without end.I am all alone and no one knows I am here,A lonely moon is mirrored in the cold pool.Down in the pool there is not really a moon;The only moon is in the sky above.I sing to you this one piece of song;But in the song there is not any Zen.Hanshan (translated by Arthur Waley, Chinese Poems, 1961)Hanshan, “Cold Mountain,” or Kanzan in Japanese, was a reclusive Chinese poet of the Tang dynasty who penned these lines in the seventh or eighth century. Centuries later, he and his kid sidekick Shide (Jittoku in Japanese) became the stuff of legends; fanciful tales of their exploits paint the pair as naturally enlightened beings prone to unorthodox behavior. The real story of their lives is lost to history; however, it seems that Hanshan lived in a deserted mountain cave near the Guoqing Buddhist temple on Mt. Tiantai, where Shide, a foundling, had been taken in by the abbot and given a menial job in the monastery kitchen. The two became fast friends, hiking the local trails together and sharing food pilfered from the temple pantry by Shide for his destitute companion.     The eccentric twosome appears frequently in Zen painting, both in China and Japan. Typically the poet Hanshan holds a scroll while Shide carries the kitchen broom, and they usually laugh uproariously for no apparent reason.  In this Japanese hanging scroll, attributed to Soga Shohaku, they amuse themselves by looking at a reflection of the moon in a pool of water, a standard Zen trope for the insubstantiality of all perceptions. As Kanzan’s poem explains, “The only moon is in the sky above,” so its reflection is but an illusion created in the cold pool of the mind. But the poem does not end with this observation; instead, Kanzan goes on to say that “there is not any Zen” in his lyric, as if to say that the “moon in the sky above” is also an illusion. In the painting, Jittoku points playfully at the “moon,” causing Kanzan to clap in pleasure at the sight. Together they delight in the fleeting moment, directly perceiving an ephemeral reality.     The painting style effectively enhances the Zen meaning of the image. Created by a follower of the individualist Soga Shohaku, who was not himself a Zen monk, the painting features brusquely applied ink washes and lightning fast lines typical of Shohaku’s work. Both techniques come from traditional Zen painting and evoke the spontaneity of deep spiritual understanding through Zen. The artist cleverly painted the moon and its reflection without truly “painting” them; instead, he left oval voids in the light ink wash that covers the rest of the silk ground. This formal technique brilliantly captures the Zen connotations of laughing at the moon’s reflection, for our minds see a void and fill it with a moon. Thus, we come face-to-face with the full emptiness of the universe.Ankeney Weitz

objects.Description: The Denis scholar Thérèse Barruel has suggested that this evening scene may well be the Cote de Versailles, le soir, that Denis sold to the dealer Ambroise Vollard in 1899. Whether or not the painting actually does represent the Cote de Versailles—a street that leads from Denis’s hometown of Saint-Germain-en-Laye in the direction of Versailles—it is safe to say that the painting is drawn from a motif near the artist’s home. Much of Denis’s production of the 1880s and1890s depended on local scenes. Denis was very much attached to his home and his family and saw little need to seek out exotic subjects for his work. His wife Marthe, his children, his friends, his surroundings, were all the subjects he desired. In his journal the devout young Denis noted how he loved his local church, where he felt at home, where he knew everyone, where “I pray for the others, and the others, perhaps, pray for me.” In 1885, well before the influence of Paul Gauguin would attract him there, the 15-year-old Denis dreamed of moving to Brittany. In his journal he spoke of how he would become the friend of the local priest and mayor in some small Breton fishing village and how he would have a little house, with a little garden, a little studio, and a little chapel, and he would keep little rabbits—the diminutives all evocative of the small family circle and humble circumstances he cherished.     This painting certainly suggests the routines and pleasures of a completely known and comfortable environment. As evening draws, the dim light mutes the colors of the landscape to tertiary values of purple, blue, and green, set off by the bright light of the interior of the tavern. One feels the welcome of a familiar stop on the way home, a place where friends may be found, and a hearty greeting expected. It is the sort of place where the French shake hands in recognition of comrades, share a drink, and then continue on home. And it is clear that Denis reveled in such known rituals and routines. And while his love of home and family would eventually lead Denis to become a royalist, and a member of the fiercely right-wing Action Française, none of that is evident in this charming painting. Nor should we construe that its safe, homey subject makes it any less artistically ambitious. Few artists in the 1890s were more daringly abstract than Denis.     Synthesizing nature, simplifying detail for expressive effect, was essential to Denis’s work of the 1890s. As a founding member of the Nabis, Denis put into practice the teachings of Gauguin on the importance of color and form in and of themselves, regardless of subject. “Remember,” notes Denis in his most quoted statement, “that a painting ... is essentially a flat surface covered with colors and shapes arranged in a certain order.” Thus the Colby painting is essentially a series of vertical brown elements played off against the sweeping arc of purplish tones at the bottom of the panel, and the flat golden band at the top. The effect is decorative and synthetic, much in the tradition of the mural painter Pierre Puvis de Chavannes, the other great influence on Denis in the 1880s and ’90s. The whole is immensely pleasing and harmonious, as comforting as the little rituals of daily life, yet as abstract and challenging to artistic tradition as anything being done at the time.Michael Marlais

objects.Dedication: Gift of The Honorable Roderic H.D. Henderson
objects.Description: Albert Bierstadt was one of the great mythmakers of the 19th century. The broader context for his remarkable contribution is the romance of the American wilderness, a narrative first enunciated in the early years of the century by Thomas Jefferson and Hector St. John de Crevecoeur, among others, and perfected during the time of Bierstadt’s greatest productivity between 1860 and 1880. At the center of that narrative is the notion that American republic is uniquely blessed with a natural setting that serves as an unparalleled spiritual and material resource for the new nation, a resource that would ensure its liberty and greatness in perpetuity.Bierstadt’s luminous landscape paintings, both great and small, are chiefly concerned with the spiritual values of wilderness. His works project a bewitching image of the American landscape, and especially the American West, as a place of the most intensely sublime beauty and grandeur. Bierstadt’s vision has a metaphysical, nearly religious quality; his nature is an Edenic paradise that radiates spiritual energy and restorative promise.     Chimney Rock is one of a number of intimate portraits of Native Americans that Bierstadt produced in the wake of his trips to the intermountain American West in 1859 and 1863. Unlike his monumental canvases, these paintings are notable for their modest scale and for their central concern with human, as opposed to exclusively natural, subject matter. In the foreground of Chimney Rock, a small Ogillallah Sioux encampment is pitched peacefully on the banks of the North Platte River; in the distant background, Chimney Rock rises dramatically from the floor of the vast plain. The late afternoon sunlight is romantically golden and smoky, as in so many of Bierstadt’s paintings, and the light and airy vastness of the distant high desert landscape contrasts strongly with the warmer and darker tones of the foreground scene. In that scene, the central subjects of the piece, several Sioux adults and a half-dozen or so children, engage in languorous domestic activities—bathing in the stream, sitting by the river bank, preparing the evening meal.     Chimney Rock and related works evoke a Rousseauian vision of Native American life. The Sioux encampment sits with perfect ease in the landscape; indeed, it seems to rise organically from that landscape. The scene has a distinctly domestic tone and conveys a profound sense of peace and tranquility. This is the uncorrupted social order that Rousseau imagined in his Second Discourse, a society deeply connected to the land and living a life of simple nobility, far from the refinements, complex needs, and dependencies of the eastern, urban world where Bierstadt painted and made his living.     The irony of Bierstadt’s vision in Chimney Rock and similar paintings is notable. Bierstadt encountered and documented the Native American way of life just as it was entering its most intense period of apocalyptic demise at the hands of settlers and the armies that made way for them. Those settlers were drawn in part by the compelling economic opportunities of the western frontier, but some, perhaps many, were also drawn by the mythical allure of the western landscape, an allure that Bierstadt did so much to create and promulgate among restless Americans in the latter half of the 19th century.William D. Adams

objects.Description: Throughout the late 1920s and early ’30s, Margaret Bourke-White produced dramatic photographs of the American machine age. Her pictures of factories, dynamos, and machines capture the power and beauty of American mass industrialization; but as the 1930s wore on, the photographer began to turn her camera toward the human subjects upon whom the devastating effects of the Depression were taking their greatest toll. On July 18, 1936, she and the novelist Erskine Caldwell embarked on a two-month journey through seven states in the American South, speaking with and photographing the people they met. They returned to the South in March 1937 for additional material; and in November of that year, they published, to great critical acclaim, You Have Seen Their Faces, their illustrated book with 75 photographs by Bourke-White and text by Caldwell. Helen Caldwell Cushman, Erskine Caldwell’s first wife, and later a resident of Mt. Vernon, Maine, gave this vintage print, along with nine others from the You Have Seen Their Faces project, to Colby in 1964.Bourke-White took this photograph of a mother and her two young children in Clinch County, Georgia, near the Okefenokee Swamp, on July 21, 1936, only three days into her travels with Caldwell. She would often photograph her subjects in various poses and settings—a practice she used in Clinch County. Two photographs of this family are included in You Have Seen Their Faces: in one instance, the family gathers for a modest meal, and in the other, the mother nurses her infant child. The photograph in Colby’s collection—an image ultimately not included in the book—depicts the mother and her two children in the close confines of their bedroom. We know some details about this family from a journal that Bourke-White kept during her travels that summer: the mother is Lizzie Steedley, a widow with two children, ages three and one, who are pictured. She lived in the house of another widowed woman, Mrs. Knight, and her twelve-year-old son, and the Steedleys received support from the county in the sum of $5.00 a month. She was unable to find work or a place of her own to live.Bourke-White’s photographs for You Have Seen Their Faces exist within the context of 1930s social documentary photography and government-sponsored programs like the Farm Security Administration (FSA) that sought to picture the economic and agricultural crises wrought by the Great Depression. Yet within this context, Bourke-White established her own unique style of documentary; her pictures of the rural South are often characterized by high drama and sentimental narrative, as in this image of Lizzie Steedley and her children. Rather than using a single flash attached to her camera, Bourke-White lit the scene dramatically from the left, casting mother and children in bright light while the area behind the bed frame is hidden in shadow. Bourke-White’s use of harsh contrasts highlights the starkness of her subjects’ social conditions. Signs of poverty fill the domestic space: bed ticking stuffed above makeshift purlins hangs over the family, and flattened cardboard boxes insulate the wall; an exposed mattress and ramshackle bed frame slant diagonally across the composition at an angle that appears to tilt Lizzie Steedley and her children into the lower left corner of the photograph. While an intimate space, this is not a picture of domestic security: this is not, after all, a home that they can call their own. The fussing infant, who leans to the left against her mother’s arm, serves to emphasize the slope of the bed and the instability of their circumstance in the face of the Depression—a time when neither present nor future conditions were certain. Sharon Corwin

objects.Description: Viviano Codazzi, born near Bergamo but most likely trained in Rome, was known as “Viviano delle Prospettive,” for he specialized in quadratura, the perspectival rendering of buildings—and indeed was one of the most important representatives of the genre of the so-called architectural pieces. This type of painting, which was primarily meant for decorative purposes, reverses history painting’s modus operandi: rather than being created to complement the action, the architectural setting comes first. Figures, added to animate the depiction, are mere “staffage” and “represent the painter’s response to the particular situation established by the architectural painter.”(1) Codazzi did not paint the figures—it is very likely that he had not been trained in that field and therefore relied on collaborators.(2)Dating from the late 1650s, Ruined Triumphal Arch, with Belisarius Receiving Alms was painted with Roman-born Michelangelo Cerquozzi, who was known in his time as “Michelangelo delle Battaglie” (Battle-Scenes Michelangelo). Cerquozzi was the only Italian among the group of painters, mostly Flemish and Dutch, who specialized in genre scenes of low life and gathered in the Strada Paolina and Via Margutta in Rome and became know as the Bamboccianti.(3) Cerquozzi and Codazzi started collaborating after the latter’s return to Rome after a Neapolitan sojourn. In fact, their first joint effort was very likely the celebrated painting of the Revolt of Masaniello of 1647–48.(4) From then until Cerquozzi’s death in 1660, they often teamed up.Codazzi’s architectural setting is a ruined triumphal arch, with engaged Corinthian columns, niches with sculptures, and panels with reliefs. It essentially is a capriccio, the combination of observed elements into a fanciful ensemble, and as such includes features that reappear in other paintings.(5) Cerquozzi placed nine figures, two women—one drawing water at a well on the left side of the canvas and another standing in the middle—and seven men, along with a dog, and a couple of horses. The “story” takes place to the right: an old man, bald with a long white beard, and dressed in rags, sits by the arch and begs, extending a cup to a man who hands him alms. To the right, stand three men, one wearing a helmet and another pointing to the beggar. They have recognized him, he is the famous general Belisarius (a helmet next to him is all that remains of his past military glory), who, despite his countless victories had been accused of conspiracy against the emperor Justinian, and, although spared from death because of his past services, was blinded and reduced to begging. The scene chosen by Cerquozzi for Codazzi’s architectural setting seems particularly fitting. After all, Belisarius, the once-heroic and celebrated general now a blind old beggar, becomes the human equivalent of the motto Roma quanta fuit ipsa ruina docet (Even ruins can teach what Rome once was)(6)—a motto that describes so well Cerquozzi’s ancient backdrop, a decrepit triumphal arch.Véronique Plesch1. David Ryley Marshall, Viviano and Niccolò Codazzi and the Baroque Architectural Fantasy (Milan: Jandi Sapi, 1993), 22.2. Marshall, Viviano and Niccolò Codazzi, 7. In a few cases the absence of figures suggests that he could not hire a collaborator.3. Giuliano Briganti, Ludovica Trezzani, and Laura Laureati, The Bamboccianti: The Painters of Everyday Life in Seventeenth-Century Rome, trans. Robert Erich Wolf (Rome: Ugo Bozzi, 1983), 3. The name came from “il Bamboccio” (ugly doll), the nickname given to Pieter van Laer because of his physical misshapenness.4. Rome, Galleria Spada. The painting represents Naples’s Piazza del Mercato, where the anti-Spanish revolt led by Masaniello in 1647 had started.5. In his entry on this painting, Marshall (Viviano and Niccolò Codazzi, 246) lists such details and the works where they can be seen.6. The motto was used by Serlio and adopted by Heemskerk for one of his drawings; quoted by Marshall, Viviano and Niccolò Codazzi, 31.

objects.Description: This pastel was one of six works by Arthur B. Davies to appear in the International Exhibition of Modern Art at the 69th Regiment Armory in New York. Opened in the winter of 1913, the Armory Show, as it came to be known, introduced Americans to avant-garde European art in the context of works by their American peers. The modest selection of paintings and drawings by Davies belied his outsized involvement in the organization of the exhibition in his role as president of the Association of American Painters and Sculptors. One of the artist’s contemporaries later ruefully observed that Davies had “unlocked the door to foreign art and thrown the key away.” The inspiration for this pastel was Nietzsche’s treatise the Birth of Tragedy (1872), in which the German philosopher argues that the Greek tragedians achieved the highest expression of art by balancing Dionysian revelry with Apollonian gravitas. In Davies’s interpretation of this dichotomy, a Dionysian chorus of repeating figures occupies a shallow foreground evocative of a stage, while the spirit of Apollo, in the form of a ghostly Kouros in white pastel, appears in the upper right of the sheet.
