objects.Description: Strange, stranger, strangest. Lynn Chadwick’s Stranger III presented a dramatic and unfamiliar sight when it first appeared on the Colby campus in 1965. The imposing bronze presence, heavy and inert, yet expressing intimations of animation and movement, produced a small controversy. I recall that the campus was divided over this new piece, a mere nine-year-old, created in 1956. In those days an example of “modern art” could still cause concern among many devotees of our Georgian columns and bricks. And while the art museum already had a fine and growing collection of 20th-century work within its walls, that confrontation could be avoided, whereas Stranger III asserted itself out on the Bixler lawn.     “I have always relied on the kindness of strangers,” said Blanche DuBois, and in The Simpsons’ musical version of A Streetcar Named Desire, the chorus sings, “A stranger’s just a friend you’ve never met.” Certainly today, Stranger III might be renamed “Comfortable Reassuring Old Friend,” since most of us who have known it for some time have developed a fond relationship. Yet from the heart of the piece and what it truly expresses, don’t we still feel the core of its original impact?     Lynn Chadwick, the sculptor, had led a low-key life involved in design and architecture until his experience as an aviator in World War II. Subsequently, he began his characteristic sculptural work, with his first solo exhibit coming in 1950, when he was already 36 years old. The distinctive sculpture of that period asserts a personal symbolism and a sometimes ominous content, manifested through powerful yet ambiguous form. Stranger III reflects life experience, not “art for art sake.” May we not infer that from the vastness of flight, during a time of war, his deeper nature was called forth as he experienced danger, exhilaration, fear, isolation, transcendence, and a gathering purpose in that realm above, apart, and so unfamiliar? Recall that flight itself in the 1940s was an unusual and strange experience.     In 1965 I was a young instructor at the college. Standing before this challenging presence, many associations would fly through my mind. Man. Wings? Birdlike. Or bat? A triad of Giacometti legs. An alien and a creature of flight—yet somehow human. No true face! The Nike of Samothrace once had one, but no one alive has seen it. A distant ancestor, yet a far different intent here. Dark victory? A fallen angel? But also like a guardian. Michael with his sword? It speaks something from within, its winglike elongation extended, pointing. Commanding? Warning? Embracing? Certainly Chadwick has given us ample emotional space in which to roam.     Regarding this acquisition, my beloved boss and mentor James M. Carpenter, first director of the Colby Museum, wrote in 1977: “The Museum’s friend and adviser, Jere Abbott of Dexter, Maine, had expressed a desire to give a piece of outdoor sculpture to the college, leaving the selection to us. He readily approved of our choice…” And Jim continued with these observations on form: Tensions abound, centered in the straight lines which retain the form of the original armature, before it was cast. These are analogous to the bones in a living creature and yet they proclaim their metallic nature. If human, Stranger III belongs to the surreal world. It seems akin to the great megaliths of stone age Britain or Ireland which also consist of rugged horizontal masses poised on vertical supports. Some of the same mystery that surrounds them seems to have been carried over into the age of flight.     Lynn Chadwick died in 2003 at the age of 88.Abbot Meader

objects.Description: A rhyton (plural, rhyta) is a serving vessel, often associated with pouring ritual libations of oil or wine. A rhyton has a larger hole to admit the liquid, and a lower, smaller one for pouring liquid out. When a thumb or finger covers the larger hole, it creates a vacuum that prevents the liquid from flowing out of the lower opening. Many rhyta are shaped like animals (theriomorphic or zoomorphic). In this fine example from Late Bronze Age Cyprus, the larger hole opens on the back of the bull’s neck, just in front of the handle, which allows the thumb to act as a stopper. Only when the thumb is raised can the liquid issue from the small opening in the mouth of the bull. The location of this smaller hole in the mouth is typical of zoomorphic rhyta. When the mouth of the animal serves as the spout, it gives a sense of animation, even life, as it appears to spew forth whatever liquid it contains. If the rhyton held red wine, the beast might have seemed to be spilling its lifeblood. It has even been theorized that the reason so many Minoan bull rhyta are found in fragmentary condition is that they had been ritually smashed as a substitute for, or imitation of, bull sacrifice.      Paleolithic cave paintings of the wild aurochs in Europe, the Bull of Heaven in the Sumerian epic of Gilgamesh, Neolithic horns of consecration on Crete, Zebu bull figurines from the Indus Valley, and the bull form of the Egyptian god Apis—all of these point to the awe that the bull inspired in prehistory. By the time of the Bronze Age, bulls had gained a central place in the art and culture of the great civilizations in and around the Mediterranean basin. The civilizations of Crete, mainland Greece, and Cyprus were no exception. Bull-leaping and horns of consecration were important features of Minoan art and architecture on Crete, while bull figurines and seal stones are ubiquitous markers of Late Mycenaean Greece. In Cyprus, the ritual significance of the bull dates back at least to the Early Bronze Age, when bucrania (bull heads) were represented on the roofs and walls of sanctuary models. Further evidence for the importance of bulls in Bronze Age Cyprus is offered by elaborate figurines depicting ritual scenes with men wearing bull masks preparing to sacrifice bulls (and possibly children).      While zoomorphic rhyta were common in Minoan Crete and Mycenaean Greece, and there are several well-known bull-head rhyta from those cultures, rhyta that take the form of a complete bull are particularly associated with Cyprus. These rhyta are frequently recovered from sanctuaries or graves. The fine, unburnished, gray-brown clay fabric of this bull-shaped rhyton, decorated with nearly vertical white stripes, mark it as a typical example of the Base-Ring II Ware, so called because the vast majority of pots of this fabric rest on a ring base. While the second phase of Base-Ring Ware has less elegant pot shapes, it compensates for that decline by the presence of beautiful zoomorphic rhyta in its repertoire, with the bull as the most frequent shape. This example’s lowered head, rather slender body, and tapering muzzle give him a more apprehensive appearance than many other bull rhyta. Maybe this bull, brimming with blood-red wine, anticipates the grisly fate that awaits animals in religious rites on Cyprus.Kerill O’Neill
objects.Disp_Title: Rhyton in the Shape of a Bull

objects.Description: Gilbert Stuart, who is today known for his many iconic depictions of George Washington, was one of the most sought-after American portrait painters during the early republic. The son of a Rhode Island snuff grinder, Stuart went on to study in Benjamin West’s London studio before becoming a popular portraitist in London, and later Dublin. After 17 years abroad, he returned to the United States in 1793 and set up a studio in Philadelphia, then in the new federal capital of Washington, DC. He settled in Boston in 1805 and enjoyed a steady stream of commissions from the city’s merchant elite until his death there 23 years later. During this time it was said that a tasteful Boston parlor was not finished until it contained at least one portrait by Stuart.This portrait—one of four by Stuart in the museum’s collection—depicts the former Miss Catherine Jones of Greenwich, Massachusetts, who married Oliver Brewster, a Boston merchant, in 1804. The well-to-do couple owned a mansion on Beacon Street, where Mrs. Brewster gave birth to five children in the first six years of her marriage. Stuart depicted her seated in a gilt Empire-style armchair. The low, lace-trimmed neckline and short sleeves of her high-waisted black velvet gown reveal her fair-skinned throat, bosom, and arms. Draped around her is a red-orange cashmere shawl—an imported luxury item that enjoyed great popularity during the early years of the 19th century. Mrs. Brewster’s brown hair is done up in a stylish “Psyche” knot with hanging side curls. Her costume and coiffure mirror those worn by the Comtesse Vilain XIIII in an 1816 portrait by the French painter Jacques-Louis David, making a date in the mid-1810s likely for this portrait.(1)Stylistically, the painting demonstrates Stuart’s willingness to experiment with both composition and technique. As was common in his portraits of this period, he placed his subject on the right side of the painting, with her body turned slightly to the left and her face looking out toward the viewer. Mrs. Brewster, however, sits unusually low within the picture, creating the impression that the viewer is standing near her chair and looking down at her, as a gentleman would do when greeting his hostess. The portrait, with its warm gray background, shows the influence of Neoclassical painters like David. Stuart’s gestural brushwork, however, owes more to English Romantic artists like Sir Joshua Reynolds, whose work he undoubtedly studied. Stuart’s approach to the painting of flesh is exemplified by his application of unblended shades of pink, peach, blue, and white with rapid strokes, which serves to animate his sitter’s face and to suggest the transparency of her skin. As the art historian Dorinda Evans has pointed out, it was painting flesh that most interested Stuart during the last ten years of his career. Indeed, a pentimento—where earlier painting shows through the final composition—in the lower right reveals that Stuart lowered the chair arm nearest the picture plane in order to reveal more of Mrs. Brewster’s beautiful skin.  A 19th-century biographer claimed that Stuart was particularly fond of Mrs. Brewster, and suggested that he intentionally prolonged her sittings as a result. Whether true or not, Mrs. Brewster appears in Stuart’s portrait to possess a warm and engaging personality. Her pose, with her hands folded demurely in her lap, is conventional. Her face, though, is full of intelligence and lively good humor. The young matron, who must have been in her mid-30s when Stuart painted her, appears on the verge of extending a hand in greeting to a favorite visitor. Lauren Lessing1. Jacques-Louis David’s 1816 portrait of Comtesse Vilain XIIII is in the National Gallery, London.

objects.Description: With its grand staircase, intimate gallery spaces, and richly painted walls, the Lunder Wing at the Colby College Museum of Art evokes the private homes where many of the artworks on view originally were displayed. Upon entering the first of these galleries, the Harriott children greet us with their bright eyes and impeccable aspect, as if to say, “Welcome to our house.”Frederick, Smith, and Estelle Harriott, children of Smith and Mary Ann Harriott of Cherry Valley, New York, posed for the artist Frederick R. Spencer in 1844. Based in New York City, Spencer often made trips upstate to paint the portraits of his wealthy clientele at their country houses. Born in Lenox, New York, in 1806, Spencer was established and well reputed in the City by the 1830s, providing masterly likenesses that later would be described as “photographic” in their effect. A student of the influential but strictly conventional portrait painter John Trumbull, Spencer received a classic academic training, including the sketching of plaster casts, at the American Academy of Fine Arts. He was admitted as a member of that Academy in 1832, and in 1846 was elected an academician at the National Academy of Design. Spencer scoffed at the developing popularity of the daguerreotype and complained of its crippling effect on the careers of painters. Nevertheless, he did respond to the growing appetite for genre subjects in the mid-19th century and attempted a number of such scenes in the 1840s and ’50s. This painting of the Harriott children, though patently portraiture, contains a note of the domestic charm characteristic of that developing subject matter.The Harriott boys, ages eight and six, sport smart fly-front pants and roundabout jackets, fashions that denote their status between boyhood and manhood. Their hair is carefully combed, their white collars starched, and their black shoes and buttons shine with the polish of refinement. Estelle is seated between them and held upright and steady by the kneeling Smith. Her coral-and-bells, with its delightful silver rattle, lies beneath the chair as if dropped haphazardly by the cherubic child. Attached to this rattle is a teething piece of red coral, a precious material often incorporated into children’s playthings for its supposed protective power. The most delicate member of the family, Estelle appears protected by her brothers and the family’s large Brittany Spaniel, whose forms create a pyramid around her, a classic compositional device that Spencer often employed. As if to emphasize the fragility of the pink-cheeked child, Spencer accentuated her diaphanous smock with uncharacteristically wispy strokes of white paint, culminating in an almost incandescent white daub just below the child’s neckline. The cap-sleeved smock was a common summer fashion for toddling children; here it creates a striking contrast to her brothers’ more substantial velvet garments.Beyond the backdrop of vermilion drapes and grand columns, the season is perhaps early autumn. The tips of verdant trees are flecked with orange and gold. The bouquet of late summer wildflowers in the foreground of the composition is perhaps a memorial to the children’s late father, who was interred in August of 1844, the same year that the portrait was painted. The bouquet appears purposefully and meticulously placed at the feet of the boy who has his father’s name. Also purposeful is the gaze of the eldest Harriott child. With his arm resting assertively on his sister’s chair, Frederick’s dark eyes pierce through Spencer’s hard-edged composition. While his siblings gaze innocently at the viewer, Frederick’s interests lie beyond the present scene.Hannah Blunt
